posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked:
Hey all!  

The MKCAD team is preparing for updates and improvements to the library for the 2025 season. Similar to past years—2024, 2023, and 2021—we utilize this thread for posting requests, fixes, new features, and issues encountered with the library or app.  

A public Trello board lists existing open items, though it may appear messy due to ongoing activities during builds and competitions. We aim to streamline it before the 2025 season begins. Before submitting a request, please review the Trello board to ensure it hasn’t already been addressed or is in progress. A future priority list will prioritize features based on usage and demand.  

Our document structure from last year continues to function well; expect only organizational improvements without structural changes.  

One request is to incorporate subcategories guided by document folders, but our featurescript library lacks the capability to navigate folders accordingly.  

We’re a small group of alumni and mentors striving to provide support. While we’re exploring student involvement, compliance with the Youth Protection Policy prevents active participation until further notice. For inquiries, DM at least two of the following: @RickyRobot, @Ty_Tremblay, or @AndrewCard.

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked: We’re still an inventor team (for now) but just started using MKCAD this year for configurable parts to 3D print and love it. We think the only thing MKCAD is missing for us is a more configurable gear generator for things like herringbone gears. The feature script we’re currently using has options like this which serve all our needs, but it would be nice if it was all in MKCAD: bore options for the common FRC inserts.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked:
This is a bit of a tricky situation. If we decide to copy the featurescript you are mentioning, we will break the connection to any updates it would get in the future from the developer who has no connection to MKCAD. We could then add our own features, but I don’t like the idea of making one specific featurescript for our uses at the featurescript level.

In my opinion, a better option for this would be to insert the gear you want as a featurescript into your part studio and then make any changes you wish to see to it, such as FIRST Robotics Competition-specific bore options, or mounting hole patterns.

We could do this as a separate configurable part in MKCAD as well, though there are quite a few configuration options available at that point. It is likely not difficult to adjust if needed.

posts.name: Dan_Karol
posts.cooked: I've noticed that the MKCad documentation library appears to be significantly more comprehensive than within the MKCad app itself. My request is to sync these automatically or have a more rigorous process to ensure updates are carried through. Another request is that occasionally, it is helpful to derive a component from an assembly into a part studio for modification. This may be a single part or a cluster of parts that should come in as a unit. The MKCad app doesn't allow for parts that only exist in an assembly (like Gearbox Plate) to be easily derived. Lastly, it would be really nice to have the ability to search by vendor and part number in the App.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
mate connectors default to hidden. Additionally, the configurable Thunderhex (and some other parts/assemblies) typically comes with visible mate connectors on each end. When attempting to hide these, simply selecting the part and clicking "hide mates" does not work as expected. To properly hide the mate connectors, navigate to the part in the feature tree (or instances list), locate the drop-down menu, and click the hide icon.  

However, after updating a large assembly, every hex shaft now displays visible mates that require manual hiding. This issue persists despite following the outlined steps, suggesting a potential configuration error.

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked:
Defaulting to hidden mate connectors is typically handled on the user side. Some documents allow users to enable or disable mate connectors entirely, but the platform does not offer control over whether they are visible or hidden from the document side.

Mates and mate connectors serve distinct purposes. Mate connectors are coordinate systems tied to each part that define alignment points. Mates describe how these coordinate systems interact, such as being fastened, rotating around the Z axis, or translating along it.

Including a checkbox for mate connectors means users can choose to have pre-made connectors available. Unchecking this option removes those connectors from the part/assembly.

Hiding mates does not affect whether mate connectors are present.Mate connectors are independent of mates.

Understanding the difference between the two helps clarify their roles. Mate connectors define alignment coordinates, while mates specify interaction types like fastening or rotation.

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked:
MKCAD contributors have control over what appears in the app, selecting which features or items are included based on specific needs or reasons such as deprecated parts, outdated models, or internal changes. There may be several items intended for inclusion that haven't yet been incorporated due to lack of attention or updates. If anyone notices specific missing components, please notify us so we can consider adding them.

These components are typically located in a dedicated workspace within the part studio rather than being displayed directly in the MKCAD app. Hiding them helps reduce visual clutter, especially for less experienced users. The best approach to bring in these parts is through the standard Onshape insert interface, which ensures visibility throughout the MKCAD environment.

Searching by vendor name remains straightforward—for instance, TTB (Thrift), AM (AndyMark), or REV. This search method looks only at the document titles, excluding metadata, so parts from different vendors aren't combinable via this route. While exploring solutions for enhancing vendor-based searches is ongoing, this current setup serves its purpose effectively.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: As someone who works occasionally on a Chromebook, I noticed that the Versa Planetary assembly includes numerous extra primitives, increasing loading times. To address this, I created a simplified version that reduces primitives by an order of magnitude and would love it to be added to MkCAD. Additionally, I'm a graduating senior, so if anyone needs assistance moving forward, please reach out. This tool has been instrumental in building our robot and enabling participation at various competitions.

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked:
After reviewing with the team and considering my recent changes to the library that are no longer present in the app, I believe there might be a genuine issue. Parts are occasionally missing from the app and require manual addition again. Initially, I thought this was due to an MKCAD contributor error, but I now doubt that explanation.  

We have asked @dydx to investigate further by adding some logging logic to track the removal process. We will monitor this activity closely in hopes of identifying and resolving the problem.  

Thank you for your understanding, and please forgive any abrupt phrasing in my previous response.

posts.name: Dan_Karol
posts.cooked:
The search only searches the title of the document, not any of the metadata, so the configurable items that are common across different vendors aren't searchable in this way.

I believe my request is for the items that are universal, such as bearings, where adding the vendor to the metadata allows them to be searched effectively. However, the MKCad app has biases toward certain vendors for specific items. For example, configurable bearings are primarily based on Vex products, though this isn't exhaustive. Additionally, there's some redundancy for configurable components that are similar but not identical.

To import those parts, the best approach would be to use the regular Onshape insert interface, which provides access to everything within MKCAD.

Could there be a power-user checkbox that displays everything? It would save time compared to navigating the backend.

Another request: Could all wheels of the same OD/hub type be grouped under a single configurable component? Ideally, this could be simplified into a single "Configurable wheel," allowing users to specify the hub style and OD, followed by a list of options.

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the text:

---

The text discusses various ideas about configuring vendor data, metadata searches, and organizing wheels. Key points include:

- The idea of letting users choose vendors for common items like bearings.
- Adding a metadata search feature to the app.
- Suggesting a power-user checkbox for comprehensive views.
- Observing how other users interact with the system.
- Proposing a super-user option to manage visibility of configurations.
- Discussing the organization of wheels based on specifications.
- Highlighting challenges in implementing such features due to varying configuration options.
- Mentioning potential limitations and alternative solutions being considered.

These ideas reflect ongoing efforts to improve system usability and functionality across different aspects of the platform.

---

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked: I was thinking more about this and have a specific example you can take a look at. 272 initially designed a gear in exactly this way one to go onto a hex shaft and another to go around a MAX Spline shaft for an encoder measurement of our shooter angle.

posts.name: Julia Schatz
posts.cooked:
**Issue Title:**  
Implement Vendor & Part Number Search Feature Request  

**Issue Description:**  
The current application lacks the capability to search by vendor and part number, restricting users' ability to efficiently locate specific resources. Enhancing the search functionality to include these filters would significantly improve usability and streamline the browsing experience.  

**Steps to Reproduce:**  
A user attempts to locate a resource by entering its part number or selecting a vendor through the application's search interface. Currently, these filters are unavailable, leading to suboptimal search results.  

**Expected Outcome:**  
Users will be able to search for resources using both vendor and part number filters, enabling more precise and efficient navigation within the application.  

**Actual Outcome:**  
At present, users cannot utilize vendor or part number filters during searches, resulting in less targeted outcomes compared to future enhancements.  

**Environment Details:**  
This issue pertains to the application running on web browsers such as Chrome and Firefox across various operating systems including Windows 10, macOS, and Linux.

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: This idea would allow users to choose where they get common bearings from. I will add this functionality to the system. Additionally, this tool could be very helpful for shaft work as well. By associating vendor names with specific part numbers, users could easily find parts during searches.
More options for bolts across all sizes would help. Something like Configurable 10-32 sized bolts.

It lacks button heads
